node.text:
How do we build resiliency in our children? Three take aways from this live with @drbeckyathome:
1️⃣Model resiliency 
2️⃣Name and value those “perfect” feelings our kids have
3️⃣Talk about our own failures

node.text:
HOW DO WE HELP KIDS LISTEN?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
This has to be one of the most asked questions whenever I do a Q&A: how do I get my kids to listen better? How do I help them be better listeners?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The listening dilemma is one where you are definitely not alone ❤️ “In one ear, out the other” never made quite as much sense until I became a parent 😂
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Today, I’m sharing five tips that I use with my family (and back when I was a teacher) to help kids listen better and reduce that parent / caregiver frustration that comes along with it 🤪
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Check out my 5 TIPS FOR HELPING KIDS LISTEN video 👆🏻 Just a few changes can make a huge difference.

node.text: ⏰OUR WAKE UP ROUTINE⏰ This is NOT an ad for tiny kid clocks 😂 although maybe I could have a side hustle as a product model? 🤷🏻‍♀️ I think I'll stick to my activities day job 😂 I have been SLAMMED (I say this lovingly) with questions lately about kids waking up in the morning, helping kids stay in beds/rooms, and ending the ‪5 am‬ "It's too early to wake up" shuffle 😱 I talk about this in my DAILY ROUTINE post (link in profile @busytoddler) but I wanted to give even more explanation 😊 My kids have these "OK TO WAKE" clocks - Mirari brand from Amazon (this company doesn't even have an IG so believe me when I say they do not know who I am) 😉 In this video, I explain the difference between the two clocks and how we use them with our kids. 👍🏻The clocks turn BRIGHT GREEN (with or without a sound) at whatever time we set them for in the AM 👊🏻 With one of our kids, this is his "it's now OK to leave your room" clock and it turns green ‪at 7:30 am‬ ➡️ For our other kids, this is their “it's OK TO WAKE, it's no longer ‪4 am‬" clocks - and it turns green ‪at 6:30 am‬ signalling to them that they are now free to play quietly in their rooms 😍 As I say in the video and the blog post (link in profile @busytoddler), our kids have safe toys in their rooms, anchored furniture, and a totally kid-approved area to play 🙌🏻 We trained them all to stay in their rooms until either we come to get them or the green light goes on ‪at 7:30 am‬ 💜 We trained them using firm, clear, and consistent boundaries - making this a big priority in our morning parenting - and for the first little bit after the crib to bed transition, we did have toddler locks on their doors for safety (I don't need a 22 month old wandering my house alone ‪at midnight‬) ❤️Obviously, we have video monitors so we can see them, and as always, do what is best / right for your family, practice safe habits, and use your judgment 🎉 In the video, I answer the big question of "don't they wake up hungry?" and in the blog post, you can find information on what I do after potty training (hint: tiny toddler toilet...) 🙌🏻 I hope our routine can help you find and develop the best wake up routine for your family 😘

node.text:
WOW - It's been almost a week since I was on GOOD MORNING AMERICA (@goodmorningamerica) and the feeling is still surreal...like I'm watching some other Mom talk about rice bins on national TV. 
I have so much to be thankful for this year - I can't even begin to list it all out. This moment, being on GMA, it really drove home just how incredible this journey has been for me. You see, my last trip to NYC (before this one) was back in 2012 with my husband, Chuck. It was a much needed getaway at a time when things were really heavy in our lives. Even though we were away on vacation, we had to pause during our trip to handle real life: we sat in a park by the Brookyln Bridge and filled out the paperwork for our 5th and final round of IVF. 
Before that, I had always thought parenthood was just this right we had and I'd never considered what it would be like to have to fight so hard for something that seemed so natural. I was so naive. That day, in New York, we didn't know if parenting was in the cards for us or what more it would take to get us there, but we were pushing forward fighting for something we believed we were destined for. Fast forward a few months and our miracle Sam was born. The final round worked and we'd made it to "parenthood". How poetic to then be back in New York, seven years later, and brought there as a sort-of "parenting expert". Me? This Mom who almost wasn't. I have so much to be thankful for and so many people to thank (I can start with the 657k of you...). Life doesn't always take the path we expect, and I am living proof of that. Thank you from the bottom of my heart for joining me on my parenting journey and for all the magic that's come with it. Happy Thanksgiving, Friends. 
With love and gratitude, Susie

node.title: Busy Toddler on Good Morning America

node.text: 🌟TRAVEL KIT🌟 aka the restaurant kit, the waiting room kit, the car ride kit, the saving my sanity since 2016 kit 🎉🎉🎉 Do you have a kit like this that's your go-to? 🙌🏻 Here's mine that I always have stocked and ready - it's a grab and go type thing - and it’s perfect for holiday events as we enter that season 🦃🎄There's a whole lot of method to the madness of what I have stored tightly into this little kit 👍🏻 The first time I made this, I had a 3 year old, a 19 month old, was having a c-section in two weeks and needed to keep my kids entertained at a company dinner for Chuck 😳 No pressure 😂 So I whipped this up before we left and our so-called “restaurant kit” has lived in my car ever since for moments when we need a little back up 💃🏻 I put all my years of Tetris & Nintendo-ing into packing this thing TIGHT 🤣. It all started with this small wipes container (like Cottonelle, Charmin,  or Scott's brand) - the container is the backbone of this operation because 1️⃣ the container can open and shut easy 2️⃣ The slit on top is perfect for shoving things through 3️⃣ It's jusssst the right size ✨ I have it full of post-it notes, dot stickers, tiny animals, match box cars, playing cards, crayons, and a partridge in a pear tree 😂Ok maybe not the last one😂 But seriously, this kit is EVERYTHING for us 🌟 the thing is: I have three kids and don't have three cell phones so a kit like this is crucial for when we go out places 🎉 I want them to learn to be a part of the action, conversation, the waiting, etc and this helps facilitate that for us - gives us a little more to do as we pass the time ⏰ What's in your "travel kit"? 🤔What's a must for your family when you go out? 🤔 Let’s pack the comments full of ideas so we can all make some amazing kits to help us during this week of car rides, dinners, and travel 🙌🏻🙌🏻🙌🏻 #busytoddleractivities

node.text:
SENSORY BINS 101 - Alright class! It's time for Busy Toddler School - jk but how fun would that be?! Let's talk all things sensory bins today - aka my most favorite activity for kids. Sensory bins are the great equalizers of play - from 12 months old to 12 years old... kids love sensory bins.

But there's a lot of questions around them: how do you make one? What do kids learn from them? And (most important) how do we keep kids from making GIANT messes with the supplies? 
I made a little video for IGTV to answer all those bin questions. Nothing holds my kids' attention quite like a sensory bin... and I want to share that magic with you all.

Cheers to happy, playing kids! XOXO - Susie

#busytoddleractivities #sensorybins #sensoryplay #earlychildhood #letthemplay

node.accessibility_caption: RESET THE DAY with a LEGO bath

node.text:
If the day hasn’t gone quite to plan,
If time is ticking backwards,
If you’re sick, the kids are sick, someone’s grumpy, someone’s trying to fuse their body to yours….

May I suggest a LEGO bath?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
It has fixed, helped, changed, and reset more days in my parenting life than I can count.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
There’s something so magical about it. And there’s nothing to it:
💦Fill the tub
🧱Add in the blocks (large Duplos or MegaBloks)
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Done.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The simplicity is what makes it perfection… that and how much it works wonders ♥️
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
TO REMOVE BLOCKS➡️
Use a colander while the tub is still full. Lay the bricks to dry on a towel. Flip them at some point to make sure all the water leaks out (a great task for little hands).

THE LADY ON THE INTERNET SAYS➡️ This has never molded my DUPLOs. Going on six years of baths with them. Haven’t had one go down the drain either (this is why I use big bricks not the small ones). But always - make choices that are best for your home & family.

On days when you need a little help, keep the LEGO bath in your back pocket. It’s everything. ♥️♥️♥️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on August 04, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, child and text that says 'WATER TABLE ACTIVITIES Swipe for ideas to play today'.

node.text:
Need to breathe some life into the ol’ water table?? I’ve got a few tricks up my sleeve 😉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I love water tables. Any water table. All kinds. I think they are a 10/10 for outdoor play & I will forever be in love with them.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
They also make for THE BEST play space especially in the summer ➡️ here’s some ways to spice up water table moments to get the kids playing, you (hopefully) sittervising, and the day running smoother 🙌🏻

No water table? NO PROBLEM! All these activities work in a storage container/sensory bin 🥰
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
SWIPE TO SEE ALL IDEAS 💡
⚗️POTIONS - add in all the science supplies and let the kids experiment 
🚜WORK SITE - scoop in some dirt and construction vehicles to make a small world
🧊ICE TABLE - dump in a bunch of ice and some water & let the kids play 
🔬SCIENCE TABLE - open some boxes of baking soda and give out vinegar. It’s the best 🙌🏻 
🧴BUBBLE FOAM - it’s a 2:1 ration of water to tear free soap, mix on high with a blender or mixer and VOILA!!!
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Remember - activities are a tool to help days go better ♥️ use when needed (and never feel guilty when you don’t 🥰)

➡️➡️ this is my beloved @thestep2company sand table that I’ve always used with water

node.text:
I call it my Union Break 😉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I found myself as a new parent trying to cram a whole day’s worth of work into nap time. It left me exhausted and a little bitter.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
So I switched gears.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I needed this time to rest, recharge, and get myself ready for the next part of the day - and frankly, I needed this a lot more than I needed to do the dishes at that exact moment.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I also had a revelation: I didn’t want my kids thinking the house magically cleaned itself. “We go to nap, we wake up, it’s clean!” I wanted them to see the hard work and care I put into our home. This is a family, this is our little community. It takes work to make it  function - and I wanted some to see that work in action.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
It also means: I do dishes instead of play. I might say no thank you to ponies because of laundry. I have to take a break from hide & seek for prepping dinner. And I’m ok with that.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
If I left all my jobs in the day to just nap time - it would be too much. Instead, I connect with my kids and fill their buckets throughout the day… and sometimes I have to say I’m busy 😘
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I take a Union break each day. Making this switch and giving myself this permission changed so much for me ♥️

node.text:
Backyard games meet Busy Toddler 🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
This is a summer tradition at our house: we started this in summer 2015 and we play it every year - this year had a particular buzz after a lot of archery viewing on the Olympic 🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
We use my “toddler tarp” aka the super cheap shower curtain liner that I’ve also had since 2015 which we use for messy activities. Works great AND it’s machine washable so win win.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I paint on a bull’s eye using washable kid paint and then we toss stuff at it. The level of sophistication in our backyard is 100%
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ 
This year, we tossed sponges. We’ve also used water blasters and water balloons 💦💦
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Two things:
1. Owning a toddler tarp is a great way to keep things “clean” for activities. Get a cheap one (dollar store or amazon). Trust me 😉
2. Tossing things at a target is always a win for children… and adults with a child’s heart 🤣♥️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Parenting Tip What should you do ifyou don't like messy play? Don't do it. (Seriously, don't sweat it) BUSYTODDLER BUSY'.

node.text:
I don’t like play dough, we don’t own play dough, and I’m fine with it 🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Friends, we often get so worried about what we aren’t doing for or giving our kids and it clouds out all the beautiful things we do offer instead. I hear this worry so often about messy play and parents not being comfortable with it.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
That’s fine!
You don’t have to do it.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
And you don’t need to feel guilty about not doing it either. Trust me, I never feel bad for the lack of play dough in our house 🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Block out the worries or the guilts and replace them with the “insteads.” I don’t offer play dough: here’s what I do offer for my kids… (insert all the amazing parts of their childhood).
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
And above all else, I offer them a supportive home, warm hugs, deep conversations, unconditional love and a strong sense of self. Focus on what you do offer, not on what you can’t ♥️

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'We give our kids the best we can, and we don't need to feel guilty about what we can't. BUSY TODDLER 1'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'If messy play isn't something you can offer right now, no worries. Remember all the things you do offer and focus on those instead. Signed, The Lady on the Internet Who Absolutely CANNOT With Play Dough (and sjust fine with that) BUSY TODDLER'.
Toss pom poms in water (they’ll dry, trust me!)

node.text:
Nothing like some pom pom magic to reset the day 🙌🏻
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
There is NOTHING like a little unexpected activity to help kids find their play ➡️ and this is an absolute favorite here.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
TOSS THE POM POMS INTO THE WATER: the bath, the kiddie pool, the sensory bin, the water table 🙌🏻 It is magical and amazing and kids don’t see it coming 🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
My kids like playing with scoops, bowls, ice cube trays, and tiny colanders (these are from Amazon) 🎉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
TO DRY THEM: Scoop out with a large colander and press the water out. Toss into a pillowcase or garment bag and into a dryer on high. Ta Da!!!
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
PS: Hoping you saw my last post about using activities as a tool 😘 and that you don’t need to do activities everyday 😉

node.accessibility_caption: Toss pom poms in water (they’ll dry, trust me!)
Pom Poms are the best in water - they’re magical!
They’re unexpected and inviting play (and here’s how to dry them)
Scoop them out with a colander, place in a pillow case, and dry on high.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 27, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'I use activities as a tool. That means that I don't do activities with my kids each day. BUSY TODDLER'.

node.text:
Yep, I don't set up an activity every day for my kids.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I view and have always viewed activities as a tool in my back pocket of parenting. Somedays, we need that tool to help us make it to nap time or rest time or dinner time. Maybe the kids are fighting or no one is playing or someone is trying to reattach their umbilical cord. That's when I pull out an activity. I use it as a reset button.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
But other days, we don't need an activity. Life is going fine. The kids are playing happily. And our day doesn't need an activity. So, I don't set one up.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I post activities here most days because somewhere, someone in the world is having a "time is ticking backwards" day. I’m happy to help and give an activity idea to reset the mood or the day or get things flowing again.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Somedays, that's what we need around here too.
Somedays, we don't. 
And I never feel guilty about which kind of day it is.

Activities are tools not necessities. Use them when needed.

node.text:
When in doubt, just add water.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
If time is suddenly ticking backwards today or you've found yourself stuck in the purgatory between naps and dinner, just add water...💦💦💦
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Here are 5 of our favorite water-based activities that are PERFECT for the backyard and to help time move in the right direction ➡️
💦The old spray bottle (and pause for a 25-month-old Sam in all his glory). He's 8 now and still loves a spray bottle in the backyard.
💦Wash the trucks: Make up some mud using backyard dirt & add in some soapy water. It's magical.
💦Paint dyed water: This works so well! Squirt some washable paint into water to dye it (but not little hands). Let the kids mix & pour.
💦Paint with water: another CLASSIC. I recommend using LOTS of different brushes to experiment.
💦Pom pom kitchen: toss the pom pom balls in with the water for an awesome "soup." (Toss the pom poms in a pillowcase or garment back and into the dryer when you are done)
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
If today is having a case of the Mondays for you, may I suggest adding water. It somehow fixes everything 💦😘💦

node.text:
“When is my birthday? When is my birthday? When is my birthday?”
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
As much fun as it is to answer that on repeat each day/hour/minute: try this instead.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
MAKE TIME CONCRETE. Aka make a paper chain countdown. Time is ABSTRACT to our kids. Unless we make it “see-able” and “touch-able” - it doesn’t compute.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
About 15-20 days BEFORE a big event (birthday, holiday, vacation), I make a paper chain countdown to mark the passage of time. Every morning, ONE link gets removed. And every time they ask when the event is, we can check the paper chain 😉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
FAQ:
⭐️ I start this around age two for kids. Even if they aren’t understanding numbers yet, they understand size. They can see the size of the chain shrinking.
⭐️ For birthdays, only the birthday kid removes links.
⭐️ For family events or holidays, the kids take turns.
⭐️ Have a baby that will destroy this? Hook the bottom of the chain back up near the top (like a loop) after the link is removed each day for safe storage - do that daily until the chain is short enough that babyzilla can’t reach it.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Make time concrete ⭐️ It’s unbelievably important AND helpful 😉

node.text:
I'm not talking "Yes Day" level of saying yes... 🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Friends, we get trapped in auto-pilot a lot in our parenting, and turning on the automatic "no" reply becomes part of our everyday words. Afterall, we know what's best for the kids, we know how to keep things running smoothing, we are the captains of the ship.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
But what if... 
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
What if we turn off the automatic No reply, and instead - do a brief pause to weigh the ask.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Could this be yes? 
Is there any real reason to say No (other than it just isn't what I had decided)?
Is there any danger in going along with their request or plan?
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Kids need a win from time to time - even something as simple as the red plate instead of the blue one.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
There is value in saying Yes to small requests from kids: it builds their independence, it grows their decision-making skills, and it helps them to see that they are a member of the family community.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Take the "yes" challenge today. Can you find even just 3 times to say "Yes" today? When you do, audit what it does for your child. Watch how it fills them up, and watch the positive impact it has on their day.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I promise, a little "yes" on something small will do so much good for your little person.

May be an image of text that says 'Consider this Being told "no" all day to every idea you have about your life and every thought or wish you think up is exhausting. It makes us question our decision-making skills, our value, and our independence. This happens to kids too. BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Give kids a win The next time your child asks for something stop and consider the request before you jump to "no." It might still be a no." Great, explain why it's a "no" and move on. But could it be a "yes?" Would it be so bad to say "yes?" BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'What it looks like This doesn't mean saying "yes" to all the toys at Target. It's saying "yes' to little requests that mean a whole lot for their sense of self, decision-making skills, and growth of independence, but won't topple family values or put kids in danger "Sure, you can eat lunch outside." "Yeah, you can wear those shoes instead." "Great idea! Let's visit that park." BUSY TODDLER'.

Photo by Susie Allison | Busy Toddler on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'One fina thought Kids need to feel that they are a valued member of the family community. They can't do this if they can't make any decisions. Make a goal today to say "yes" to them. Watch what it does to their confidence and how it changes their mood. Remember, a little "yes" goes a lot farther than a non-stop "no." BUSY TODDLER'.

node.text:
Have you made frozen paint? 🎨🧊
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
You know how some people are great at always having a freezer or dump meal saved and waiting for when they really need it? Frozen paint is my dump dinner activity 🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
I pop this into the freezer on a day when things are going GREAT and the next time things AREN’T… Past Susie and Frozen Paint to the rescue 🙌🏻😱🤣
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
SOME FAQ:
I use washable tempera paint from @discountschoolsupply - it works great! Once I crack these little paint-sicles from the ice cube tray, I set them in a tiny bit of warm water to help start the painting process.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Pull open my freezer and 9/10 you’ll find half eaten ice cream, most of the Trader Joe’s freezer section, and an ice cube tray of frozen paint for just such an occasion when the kids and I need it 😉
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Pop some in your freezer today - Future You will be really glad you did 😘😘
